instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PLT_RST_L: What is PLT_RST_L? This is an abbreviation of “PLT_RESET_L” – when you see “PLT_RST_L", assume the person meant to type PLT_RESET_L.
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Chimes sound loop, no display just backlight - 20V 1.95A
threads.message:
Hello everyone.
I need help, please.
Got this Mac in to repair, and it's stuck on chime sound, sound is cycling, video link showing the issue.
[MEDIA=youtube]TmEvcaIiv2A[/MEDIA]
It gets backlight, but no display.
BIOS flashed with another Clean ME firmware and still the same.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 13.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.41V
<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.15V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.36V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 3.35V
<SIGNAL>PP1V0_SUS</SIGNAL> = 1V
<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.36V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN_R</SIGNAL> = 3.24V

Diode mode on:
L7430 <SIGNAL>CPUGT_SW3</SIGNAL> - 0
L7420 <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_CPU_PH3</SIGNAL> - 0
L7410 <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> - 0
L7210 <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> - 0
L7220 <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL>- 0
L7270 <SIGNAL>CPUVR_SWSA</SIGNAL> - 0.14
All the other coils are measuring similar to a working board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Chimes sound loop, no display just backlight - 20V 1.95A
threads.message:
How do you get <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> high without CPU core voltage?
Please check again...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Chimes sound loop, no display just backlight - 20V 1.95A
threads.message:
The CPU VCORE voltages I mentioned above is for DIODE mode. Not Voltages.

Voltages is.
L7430 <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL> - 0V
L7420 <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_CPU_PH3</SIGNAL> - 0V
L7410 <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> - 0Vv
L7210 <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> - 1.08V after about 8 secs drops to 0.64V
L7220 <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL>- 1.08V after about 8 secs drops to 0.64V
L7270 <SIGNAL>CPUVR_SWSA</SIGNAL> - 1.05V after about 8 secs drops to 0.77 for 6 secs then stays at 0.85V

L8000 - <SIGNAL>PP1V_PCH_REG_R</SIGNAL>
L8050 -

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Chimes sound loop, no display just backlight - 20V 1.95A
threads.message:
0 in diode mode means pure short; is not same as 0.002 for example.
In the future, post accurate information and avoid missunderstood like above.

Disconnect touch ID and keyboard; see if gets image, or test USB activity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Chimes sound loop, no display just backlight - 20V 1.95A
threads.message:
I've checked on another working board and measurements in
Diode mode on:
L7430 <SIGNAL>CPUGT_SW3</SIGNAL> - 0
L7420 <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_CPU_PH3</SIGNAL> - 0 
is same as on the faulty logic board.

L7430 <SIGNAL>CPUGT_SW3</SIGNAL> - 3.2 Ohms
L7420 <SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_CPU_PH3</SIGNAL> - 3.2 Ohms
Is this normal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Chimes sound loop, no display just backlight - 20V 1.95A
threads.message:
CPU core and iGPU coils have very low resistance to ground as normal.

"L7430 <SIGNAL>CPUGT_SW3</SIGNAL> - 3.2 Ohms"
This should be something like 0.002-0.004 in diode mode.
Why do you write just 0???

"L7210 <SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> - 1.08V after about 8 secs drops to 0.64V"
This voltage should fluctuates, if chimes in loop.
Check if is the case.

Test what happens in SMC bypass and safe mode.
You can try known good BIOS.
